instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-01190: What is 820-01190? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that was working fine until the battery got low and I went to plug it in and it wouldn‚Äôt charge. It slowed to a crawl, I tried a restart, it went through a couple of instances of the fan cycling and now just shows the charging indicator on the screen if holding a button down. This says to me that the battery supplies power to the computer fine, it‚Äôs a charging problem.

Is there a way to charge the battery without going through the USBC port? This is my first MacBook repair and if I can charge the battery, I can get a backup before I do anything that might permanently Bork the computer.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be sure to use original 87W charger.
What is the 820-xxxxx MLB code?

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message: Hi! Thanks :) I‚Äôm trying to figure out where I find that value but after scouring Google and the back of my logic board for the last five minutes I‚Äôm getting nowhere. Any tips on where it would be? I‚Äôll keep looking

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message: I suppose I should also mention that I‚Äôm getting 5v, 0.020ma, and around 300 ohms on the reader. Based on all of the videos I‚Äôve seen so far, there is an issue with the charging circuitry which is why I was wondering if there was a simple way to bypass

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
Edit: I had the wrong value. See [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] post below.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî original message below‚Äî‚Äî-
For anyone who finds this post later, it‚Äôs under the battery clip.


(search: where is the mlb number on my MacBook Pro)

My value is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01190</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
I asked about MLB (Main Logic Board), not battery electronics board.
You should find a code like <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, or <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.ebay.com/itm/254806166120[/URL]
Check the fourth picture there.

"Be sure to use original 87W charger."
???

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message: Gotcha! Thanks for the pointer. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04. I didn‚Äôt realize there‚Äôd be two numbers starting with the same 3 digits and when I found that one I was like, ‚Äúaha! This must be it!‚Äù And it wasn‚Äôt üòÖ

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message: ‚ÄúBe sure to use original‚Äù - oh yeah. I‚Äôve done that. I tried with multiple MacBook chargers. I took her apart and found some corrosion near the vents and brushed that out so as far as I can tell, everything looks clean. But still getting the 5v 20ma reading.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
[QUOTE="willyboy, post: 98099, member: 47353"]
‚ÄúBe sure to use original‚Äù - oh yeah. I‚Äôve done that. I tried with multiple MacBook chargers. I took her apart and found some corrosion near the vents and brushed that out so as far as I can tell, everything looks clean. But still getting the 5v 20ma reading.
[/QUOTE]
But using the original block with the meter was really important to isolating the problem chip. All but one do the cycling behavior that the other posts say means those are good.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message: Just touching base on this. The only idea I‚Äôve come up with is to get another logic board that I could use to charge the battery and then switch the old one back in once it‚Äôs charged.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
"Original" but 87W???
This board doesn't turn on with 61W, if battery is fully drained.
Better to have a 96W, or even 140W original charger in service; then you can test any MacBook.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
Yes, it‚Äôs an 87 watt charger. There is a bad CD32 chip based on the fact that 3 out of 4 of the USB C connections cycle power. I can check those connections in your post when I get home but to be clear, I‚Äôm not trying to solve that right now. I just want to be able to charge the battery without going through that chip. I was hoping there would be some hack to do that. 
If I got another logic board with a working chip, I assume that would work but it seems like overkill.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message:
All USB-C ports are related.
You can't charge the battery in other way on this board.

If you deal with laptop repairs (Apple or not), get this:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.laptopu.ro/[/URL]
Then you can test and charge/discharge any laptop battery.
Buying the license, you can even repair some of them.

threads.title: Charge <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> without using USB-C port
threads.message: Just as a follow up for anyone who finds this later, I was able to use a new board to charge the battery so that I could get a backup before mucking with anything important.
